data.note: There are an three minigrids in the country - one hydro, one solar and one biomass. These are supported by the Rural Electrification Authority.
data.name: Mini-grids: licensing

data.note: Licenses designate a territory around the minigrid area, which offers the owner some protection against competition from the grid, effectively a concession agreement.
data.name: Mini-grids: concessions

data.note: Regulations apply for projects or minigrids above 100kW. The regulator will normally let self-supply or community-supply projects go without a license, but if it is a commercial entity selling electricity to consumers, even below 100kW, the regulator will demand a licence.
data.name: Mini-grids: threshold

data.note: This is the Energy Regulation Board.
data.name: Dedicated regulator

data.note: The commercial team in the utility is responsible for any power producers selling power to the grid but there is no official, separate minigrid or small-project team.
data.name: Dedicated team within utility

data.note: The regulator strives for a light-handed approach. It will assess price and technical set up but does not place a prohibitive burden on small power projects. For instance, there is a combined license to generate, distribute and supply electricity at a small-scale, where each of these elements requires a separate licence at large scale.
data.name: Light-handed regulatory framework

data.note: The regulator will check that prices are cost-reflective, but will not specify a level.
data.name: Cost reflective tariffs

data.note: The regulator reserves the right to check tariffs are cost-reflective, and there is a contract provision for price review.
data.name: Stable tariff guaranteed

data.note: The developer has relative freedom to set price levels.
data.name: Tariff deregulation

data.note: This is starting to be deployed through the 'Scaling Solar' and 'REFiT' (renewable energy feed-in tariff) programmes. There is no standardised PPA available at the utility.
data.name: Standardised PPAs

data.note: The PPA duration under 'Scaling Solar' is 25 years, which is sufficient to be bankable.
data.name: PPAs of sufficient duration

data.note: PPAs have to be secured and Zesco is not obliged to purchase the power.
data.name: Purchase obligation

data.note: Projects below 20MW in the 'REFiT' (renewable energy feed-in tariff) will use standard regulation in the PPAs. Projects above 20MW will use the normal grid rules, agreed in a PPA with Zesco.
data.name: Clear rules on interconnection

data.note: The licence for small power projects and minigrids protects the area of service, meaning that the state utility cannot take customers when the grid arrives. More clarification is needed to allow these projects to connect when the grid arrives.
data.name: Clear rules on arrival of the main grid

data.note: The Office for Promoting Private Power Investment has grid extension plans that are accessible to new developers. The utility does not make plans available online.
data.name: Transparent grid extension plan

data.name: Rural electrification agency

data.note: The main document is the Rural Electrification Master Plan. It was published in 2008 and aims to increase electrification in rural areas from 3% to 51% by 2030. We estimate the current level of rural electrification at 5% (see energy data section). The Rural Electrification Authority estimates that this will cost about $50m/yr over the period 2008-30.

data.note: The Rural Electrification Agency's remit involves developing off-grid energy projects but has no specific targets.
data.name: Offgrid energy access target

data.note: Power Africa Beyond the Grid and the Swedish Development Agency are two organisations active in this area.
data.name: Offgrid financing facilities

data.note: The Rural Electrification Agency has a programme to install off-grid solar and hydro projects, but it builds and operates these itself. There are no grants for mini-grid operators.
